title: popular-teacher-retires-ross-high-school
story: Gordon Muchall, an additional support needsteacher at the Tranent secondary school, has been praised for his work encouraging outdoor education and giving young children new and positive opportunities.From Edinburgh, Gordon followed a dferent path to most teachers, having been a partner in a law firm and a Catholic priest before giving it up and following a career in teaching.He said: ldquoIt felt like quite a natural progression. I had a broad range of experiences to bring to the job.ldquoWhen I was a priest, I was chaplain at the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh, dealing with people who were grieving, and I also visited special needs schools in Fe, and it was these visits that got me into teaching.ldquoLeaving the priesthood was a decision that I thought long and hard about, and in the end decided that it was the right move and I have no regrets. I trained as a teacher and got a job at Ross High over nine years ago.ldquoI was keen to bring a lot of outdoor learning to my work. I encouraged the children to climb hills, try kayaking and canoeing, rugby, things that a lot of the parents never thought their children could do.ldquoIrsquom a rugby referee as well, so naturally encouraged the children to play rugby, and to join the school choir and things.ldquoSeeing how happy they were and the smiles on their faces is something that I will really miss.Gordon is planning to move to the Isle of Mull to spend his retirement with his we.ldquoWersquore quite outdoorsy, we do a lot of hiking and kayaking, he said.ldquoOur house will be right on the waterfront, so I am very looking forward to it.ldquoIrsquove enjoyed myself, but I think itrsquos time for younger blood to take over, and I can give myself a rest!Jillian Binnie, depute head teacher ASN at Ross High, said: ldquoGordon has made a huge contribution to the ASN provision and Ross High School as a community, especially in driving the introduction of an outdoor education programme that allows all of our young people, even those with the most severe and complex needs, to take part.ldquoHe has a calm, non-judgemental approach to dealing with any challenges he might face on a daily basis.ldquoHe shows all of our young people unconditional positive regard and has built strong relationships with both our young people and their families. He is also a much-valued team member.ldquoWe all wish him well in his retirement.

title: calls-create-car-park-aldi-moves-new-site-haddington
story: Aldi is among the businesses named in a planning application for a retail park on Haddingtonrsquos western edge.Those proposals are still being weighed up by the council but,approved, it could see Aldi move from its current home off Whittingehame Drive to the new development at Gateside West.That would leave an empty site, with community councillors in the town suggesting that the council look into creating a new town centre car park there.Jan Wilson, chairwoman of Haddington and District Community Council, was among those backing the idea.She said: ldquoThat would be a great thing to happen because we are needing the spaces.ldquoEast Lothian Council have bought [the hospital site at] Herdmanflat and,they can buy over that, I hope they would be able to buy Aldi, although I am surprisedAldi were moving.Concerns about town centre parking have been raised on a regular basis, with fears that there are not enough spaces to ensure people can use the townrsquos businesses.Paul Darling, one of the community councilrsquos planning liaison officers, also felt it was worth weighing up the idea of transforming the site.He said: ldquoIf [the council] can buy it, that would be great.ldquoButsomebody is there saying it is a brand new shop and they can walk in, change the logo and open, they are going to put in a slightly higher bid than what the council can put in.Pat Lemmon, who works in the town centre, felt it was a good location for a potential car park.She said that changes planned for the town centre were suggesting parking spaces could be lost and an alternative ldquohad to be found.The community councillor told the Courier: ldquoI cannot see East Lothian Council giving up their car park or the long-stay car park at Tesco, which they seem to fill up first thing in the morning. Another car park has been mooted for a long time.However, echoing Mr Darlingrsquos view, she felt that it was more likely that another supermarket or retailer would move into the siteAldi decided to move.The town centre site has been home to a supermarket for more than  years, with Aldi setting up shop about a decade ago.When the plans for the retail park at Gateside West were lodged, the supermarket giants distanced themselves from any potential move, despite being named in the plans ndash along with coffee chain Costa and Home Bargains ndash as ldquoend occupiers confirmed for the site.A spokeswoman for Aldi said the new store was ldquonot currently on our radar.The Gateside development would be made up of three retail units, two restaurants cafes and a drive-thru takeaway, with Greggs and The Food Warehouse also linked.A petrol station and retail unit are also being earmarked for the site.Currently, the Aldi store site has more than  parking spaces but that number would increasethe supermarket building were demolished.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoThese are speculative comments and we believe that Aldi has dismissed rumours that they may move location.ldquoIn general terms, any changes of use to sites within Haddington would be open to consultation with local residents and businesses.

title: new-museum-exhibition-celebrates-history-musselburgh-festival
story: Past Honest Lads and Honest Lasses have rallied round with support by donating items of memorabilia for the display, which includes photographs of past events, riding boots, stirrups and a riding crop.The iety of gts presented by local industries and the community to Honest Lads and Honest Lasses at sashing ceremonies can been seen, as well as trophies for events such as the Honest Ladsrsquo Race, Ladiesrsquo Race and Crusaders Riding Club competition.There is a chance to get a close-up look at sashes embroidered with the names of every Honest Lad and Honest Lass from  to  and the Burgh Standard, which plays an important role during the annual festival.Official outfits worn by the Honest Lad and Honest Lass are exhibited, as well as programmes, pennants, the first minute book for festival organisers the Honest Tounrsquos Association and words for the Musselburgh Song. Information is on show about the carriage used on election night, when the official party is transported through local streets to waving crowds.The birth of the festival in , when Jimmy Arthur was Honest Lad and Ina Vass, Honest Lass, is also outlined.This yearrsquos Honest Lad Aidan Maguire, Honest Lass Claire Dougal and attendant Abbie Thomson were amongst the first to enjoy a tour of the exhibition after their recent visits to local primary schools and Musselburgh Grammar School.Stefanie Talac, honorary secretary of the Honest Tounrsquos Association , said this was the first exhibition about the festival at the museum and they hoped that as many people as possible would pay it a visit.She said: ldquoWe are delighted at the way the exhibition has turned out. We had a lot of help from past Honest Lads and Honest Lassies.ldquoThere is a beautully bound photograph album from the Honest Lass of  which was presented by the local paper mill. Our th year Honest Lass was presented with a travel iron from Brunton Wire Mill. The connection with the fishing community in Musselburgh is also shown in the gts with a ship in a bottle and model boats.She added: ldquoDuring the festival, the Honest Lass pins a pennant to the top of the flag and it has the Honest Ladrsquos name on it. Each pennant is in the museum as well.Stefanie said that while the festival is on from July  to  this year, some of the display items will be removed as they will have a part to play in the event itself, before being ed to the museum afterwards.She added: ldquoThe museum is a great asset to the town. We are really pleased that we have had the opportunity to have the exhibition in the museum. It is the first since the museumrsquos inception and hopefully we will do so again in the future. The exhibition is here for people who want to learn more about the festival and we hope they do.The museum at  High Street is open Thursday to Saturday, .am to pm.

title: tim-39-s-tales-naming-new-town
story: WHAT is history  It isnrsquot actually what happened in the past. History is the way we view and see things that happened in the past. That view is limited by a number of factors. The availability of surviving records and evidence is one.The vast majority of what happened in the past is inevitably lost to us. This is true even for our own personal memories. So history is the small tip of the iceberg of events and times gone by, brought to the surface by the survival of some accounts more than others.And these records are never unbiased. Often historical records and evidence are purposely partial, influenced by ideology and personal allegiances. But all are biased in some way, as the limited viewpoint and interests of those recording events is based on their experience or motives.As a result, we can only see historical events through a narrow keyhole, with most characters and goings on out of view. Itrsquos the common people who are most always invisible in history. Our own ideological preference and belief in what is important will then affect how we interpret the limited evidence we have.This is why history is often subject to furious debate, and rightly so. Irsquod say itrsquos almost impossible not to allow our own perspectives, interests and values to influence the way we interpret the broader meaning of historical events and their signicance for contemporary society.Such a debate is being had in East Lothian just now, as to the name of the new town to be built on the Blindwells site, between Prestonpans and Longniddry and just to the north of Gladsmuir and Tranent.The name can be romantically translated to mean lsquohidden springsrsquo and it was across this once-marshy ground that the Jacobites crept stealthily at night to mount a surprise attack on the Redcoats on September , . That famous battle lasted  minutes and was a victory for the Jacobites, and the launchpad of Bonnie Prince Charliersquos march into England.Consequently, the Scottish Battlefields Trust has submitted a petition, as reported in the Courier last week, to name the new community Charlestoun and build a statue of Charles.When I was at school, he seemed a dashing and heroic figure. The songs and stories about him are infectious and I totally understand how the stories told about him have created a romantic and thrilling image.But then I studied the topic in more depth, at both university and afterwards. The period has suffered from the romantic treatment but there are fascinating stories of loyalty and sacrice to a man who, in reality, saw the common people chiefly as cannon fodder for his personal and family ambitions.It is for this reason I feel there are enough name places and statues to aristocratic and powerful men whose main historical role was to make and wage war, evenhe has a famous and romantic reputation.This is not to say we shouldnrsquot remember the fascinating history of the area, including that fateful day of battle when the Jacobites crossed the land.But itrsquos how we commemorate it and who we include. What makes the Jacobite period truly fascinating is the tapestry of stories of the many people involved, on both sides. It was a brutal time, in which there was certainly deep loyalty on both sides, but there were many other reasons why people found themselves on one side or the other. It was a brutal civil war, brought on by the aspirations of the exiled Stuarts.Do we commemorate the memory of the man who caused that war or do we commemorate those who were caught up in it  Is it really the case thatwe do the former we do the latter  Irsquom not convinced.There are other stories to consider of course for the site. There was coal mining there for generations. The lives of mining families, men, women and children who toiled in horric conditions, still remains mostly unheralded by history. Maybe itrsquos not lsquoromanticrsquo enough. Likewise with farming, which was a constant economic activity in the area for generations.There was also another unusual underground activity on the site after the early mine closed. Smugglers made an illegal whisky still deep down in the mine shaft once it was disused. It took a while for the customs men to realise East Lothian had an illicit whisky-making enterprise deep below ground in the old mine workings. When they finally raided the mine, they found the still, but no sign of the makers of the whisky. It kind of gives new meaning to the name lsquohidden springsrsquo!It is suggested the children in schools should have the final say in the new name, which is a great idea. But let our children be introduced to all aspects of our local history and allow them to understand how the way history is taught influences what we believe is important in contemporary society as well, and that there is no lsquocorrectrsquo view on this.Irsquod love to be part of that discussion and debate.

title: parents-launch-petition-school-bus-operator-change
story: Families whose children attend two secondary schools in East Lothian were stunned to discover that local firm PrenticeCoaches would no longer be used to transport the youngsters when schoolsafter the summer.The news was broken to them by Prentice, which is based in Haddington, last week, sparking a furious reaction from a number of parents.Now a petition has been launched calling for Prentice to have the contract, which has allegedly been awarded to a rival firm, given back.One mother whose children attend Knox Academy in Haddingtonand are bussed in from Gford said that she was shocked by the news.She said: ldquoPrentice have been looking after our children for  years and they are being replaced with no consultation or discussion.ldquoParents know the drivers and trust them to look after their children.ldquoIt is beyond belief that the council would simply put a dferent company in place without even consulting with the families affected.A petition calling for theof Prentice has collected more than  signatures since it was launched online.It says: ldquoPrentice provide a community service where parents feel reassured and comfortable putting their children on the buses.ldquoWe believe East Lothian [Council] has chosen to put cost over service and safety.ldquoThere is absolutely nothing wrong with the current service.ldquoThis is simply a cost-cutting exercise which could potentially put our children at risk.Prentice provided bus services for Knox Academy and North Berwick High School but has now lost the contract for those services.Ross Prentice, the company boss, admitted that he was ldquodisappointed by the councilrsquos decision.The company said: ldquoIt is a sad day. We have operated the Knox routes continuously for over  years.ldquoWe would like to thank all the pupils and parents who we have transported over the years for being so friendly and their excellent behaviour, and wish the current pupils all the best for their futures.A spokesman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoAs the previous contract had expired, the council was required to carry out an open procurement process to appoint an operator for the service.ldquoAs the contract is yet to be formally awarded, we cannot provide further detail at this stage.ldquoHowever, we can assure families that tenders have been assessed in line with all requirements, standard procedure and quality criteria. In the event of a new operator being appointed, other aspects of the service will be unchanged.The petition can be found at you.degrees.org.uk petitions reinstate-prentice-buses-as-knox-academy-school-transport-provider

story: Jacqueline Johnstone, of St Germains Terrace, was caught drink-driving at Gilbert Avenue in North Berwick.Johnstone, , was found to have mg of alcohol in ml of breath during the incident ndash the legal limit is mg.She appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court, where she pleaded guilty to the offence, which took place on May .Sherf Pamela Bowman banned Johnstone from driving for  months and fined her pound.She was allowed to take part in a drink-driving rehabilitation scheme which could reduce her ban by a quarter.

title: north-berwick-high-school-roll-set-top-1-000-extension-planned
story: The school, which welcomes pupils from the surrounding villages as well as North Berwick, currently has a school roll of .However, that figure is expected to increase, with the town continuing to grow and the school set to become the fourth secondary school in the county with more than , pupils.Three extensions ndash in ,  and  ndash have already been carried out on the school to accommodate the growth of the town.Now, the proposed extension would cater for a school roll of up to ,.Plans submitted to East Lothian Council note: ldquoThe completed building will provide state-of-the-art teaching and social space facilities in line with the clientrsquos brief as well as promoting energy efficiency and offering facilities which signal the high value placed on learning at North Berwick High School.ldquoThe project is to reflect the standards commensurate with a modern school facility and provide a high-quality environment that will inspire both staff and young people to achieve their full potential.The proposed extension would occupy an area to the south-west of the existing buildings, bordered by the synthetic pitch and the site boundary with the schoolrsquos neighbours Law Primary School.The document states: ldquoThe location of the proposed extension will offer views out over the sports pitches and towards North Berwick Law.The ground floor of the three-storey extension will become home to the home economics department, with a shared social and exhibition space.Social sciences will be based on the first floor, with the languages department on the second floor and ldquolarge shared breakout spaces at the heart of the floorplan.The plans from Innovate East Lothian Ltd, which is acting on behalf of East Lothian Council, could go before the local authorityrsquos planning committee later this year.Currently, Dunbar Grammar School , Musselburgh Grammar Schooland Ross High Schoolin Tranent all have more than , pupils.

title: council-remove-recycling-wheelie-bins-contamination
story: East Lothian Council is one of the few local authorities in Scotland to retain recycling boxes for most of its households and has a  per cent recycling rate ndash higher than the national average.However, Tom Reid, the councilrsquos head of infrastructure, revealed that it had rolled out , communal recycling bins in small communities and densely populated streets.But, he said, the result had been a much higher contamination level in the recycled waste which suggested thatbins were rolled out across the county it could cost the council up to poundmillion. The bins, first used in , are now being removed by the council and replaced with inidual boxes.Mr Reid told a meeting of the councilrsquos policy and performance review committee that the bins had not been a success.Councillor Gordon Mackett asked why wheelie bins could not be used, saying he was told by people they ldquowould recycle morethey had wheelie bins.But Mr Reid said: ldquoUsing the boxes produces a higher quality of recycling waste and we currently sell it for up to pound,.ldquoWe have , wheelie bins out there and the result has been a disappointing  to  per cent contamination.ldquoIf we moved to wheelie bins we would have to pay out between poundmillion to poundmillion to decontaminate the materials.A council spokesperson said the recycling bins had already been removed from some parts of the county, with the rest expected to be replaced by boxes in the near future.

title: Iain Macwhirter  You   ll have had your Indyref2 - the Tory leadership contest has made clear the gloves are coming off
story: Actually, what she told Nicola Sturgeon in March  was that ldquonow is not the time for Indyref, which is rather softer than the hard line her would-be successors are taking. Now its never. A flat no. Forget it. Youll have had your referendum.Both Boris and Hunt made clear at the Perth Hustings that there will be no independence referendum, eventhe SNP win outright in . Thats a sobering message for the independence movement, and for Nicola Sturgeon. She still regards the Section  route to a legally-binding referendum as the only plausible one. That is now road-blocked.There has been a dramatic hardening of rhetoric against Scotland during this campaign. Theresa May came to Stirling to proclaim that Nicola Sturgeon ldquocannot be trusted. That the Scottish government is incapable of negotiating ldquoin good faith. Why, Sturgeon had the temerity to portray the UK governments takeover of powers repatriated from Brussels as a ldquopower grab. You just cant deal with these people, May concluded.We all know what Boris Johnson thinks about Scotland. A nation of ldquofreeloaders. He described Scotland having free care and free tuition as ldquopretty monstrous. Jeremy Hunt has tended to be more emollient, but on Friday his gloves came off too. He condemned the Scottish Government as: ldquothe most bullying, isive, duplicitous, anti-business government Scotland has ever seen.Given that the Scottish National Party dominates the opinion polls, and has more seats in both parliaments than all the Unionist parties put together, this could be taken as an oblique criticism of the Scottish voter. I mean, are Scots so stupid that they dont realise they are being run by bullying charlatans  Its almost asthey cant be trusted to know their best interests, deluded as they are by the hypnotic rhetoric of separatism.This was all rather redolent of how British imperialists, like Churchill, used to talk about nationalist leaders in the old British colonies. They were all wily demagogues, up to no good. Cant trust them as far as you can throw them. The subtext was: the only language they understand is firmness. Just tell them what the score is and let them get on with it.This is very much the line taken in the Dailylast week by the Thatcherite former Scottish Secretary, Lord Forsyth of Drumlean. He says that the real threat to the Union comes from ldquogiving in to Nationalists demands. The Tories best bet is to tell them politely but firmly that they can stick their independence up their Great Glen ndash or words to that effect.All this is, of course, exactly what the SNP want to hear. There is nothing better for drumming up support for the Nationalist cause than hearing a phalanx of crusty Tory grandees telling Scotland to like the Union or lump it. Support for independence is creeping up ndash slowly but steadily ndash and is now % in the latest polls, and %Boris Johnson wins.True, demand for an early referendum on Scottish independence is certainly muted. But after Mr Johnson enters Number Ten ndash a racing certainty according to the latest YouGov poll ndash and a no deal Brexit looms, things could move fast. The SNP expect support for Yes, which has been stuck for five years, to jump dramatically. Possibly approaching that % which Nicola Sturgeon allowed the media to speculate back in  was the threshold for calling a repeat referendum.But its going to be messy. There is already disquiet in the party and in the wider Yes movement at the SNP leaders apparent lack of enthusiasm for leading the independence revolution. But after this Tory leadership campaign, she can be in no doubt that there has been a sea-change in attitudes to Scotland from the governing party. No more Mr Nice Guy. Scots will have to learn to love Brexit Britain or take the high road out of the Union.Yet, its a little odd that Scotland should have become such a touchstone issue in the Tory leadership race. There are hardly any Tory members in Scotland, after all, and it is they wholl be doing the voting in the campaign, which is now reaching peak empty promise as the ballot papers go out. But both contenders seem to have chosen to make the Union and Scotlands place in it central to their respective campaigns.They each claim, rather improbably, to have an almost religious attachment to the Union. Its blood-in-my-veins stuff for Hunt. The ldquomost successful Union in history according to Boris Johnson, clearly believing that the United States somehow fails to qualy as a union.Perhaps this relates to something deep in the Conservative psyche: that Great Britain needs to retain its subject nationalities to prove that it is still a going concern. Certainly, the loss of Scotland - taking with it a third of the UK landmass, most of its hydrocarbons and all of its nuclear weapons - would be a devastating blow to Brexit Britain. The UKs prestige, already diminished as a result of the three years of chaos and indecision, would take an even greater knock. It could lose its place on the UN Security Council, become an empty chair at G Summits...So, there was a bit of carrot to go along with the stick. Boris Johnson has declared himself ldquoMinister for the Union with the implication that devolution is now as important to the Prime Ministers role as First Lord of the Treasury . He is going to take Scotland well in hand, and ensure that all policies in future are stress tested for compatibility with all four nations.Jeremy Hunt too came bearing gts. Scotland is to become a ldquogreen Silicon Valley, a post-Brexit digital entrepocirct. He presumably avoided saying ldquoSilicon Glen because that would have reminded Scottish voters of what happened the last time Scotlands future was predicated on new technology, back in the days when the Tory George Younger ran the Scottish Office.At its height, in the early s, Scotlands technology industry made one third of all the computers manufactured in Europe. Not any more. They went where as the UK de-industrialised under Margaret Thatcher. Mr Hunt also hyped his proposal to slash corporation tax to .% - something Alex Salmond used to argue for. However, this is a policy for the UK as a whole, not Scotland, so there is no obvious comparative advantage, still less any promised to devolve business taxes.But the headline message from both Tory candidates in the Perth hustings was withering contempt for the independence movement. This will no doubt please Conservative members in the southern shires, who have already largely given up on Scotland and regard the Union with pointed indference. As YouGov discovered recently, the vast majority would willingly let Scotland goit meant saving Brexit.They may get their way sooner than they think.

title: snp-mp-joanna-cherry-qc-made-citizens-assembly-39-ten-times-harder-39-says-adviser
story: Dr Oliver Escobar suggestedthecomment by Joanna Cherry QC last week wasso unhelpful it had made the forumswork ldquoten times harder.He told the Herald such commentsmade it harder becauseunderstanding of the Assembly was still in its infancy and it had yet to gain public trust.That meant people might not distinguish between Ms Cherry speaking as a politician with onepoint of view, and the entirely separate, independentorganisationofthe Assembly.Announced by Nicola Sturgeon in April as a way of thrashing out the long-term challenges facing Scotland, the Assembly has been dogged by claims it is a Nationalist front.Based on the Irish models which led to referendums legalising same-sex marriage and abortion, the Assembly will recruit its first  members and  substitutes over the summer, then deliberate over six weekends from later October to late April.In Ireland, cross-party buy-in and independence were vital factors in the exercisersquos success.However the Scottish Tories and Scottish LibDems have already said they will have nothing to do with the Scottish version, with Unionist campaigners urging a boycott.Last week its first co-convener David Martin, the former Scottish Labour MEP, appealed for cooperation and insisted the forum would be independent from the SNP Government.However a day later Ms Cherry, the SNPrsquos justice spokeswoman at Westminster, fuelled Unionist suspicions by saying the Assembly was part of a wider independence effort.In an online video, she described it as ldquothe perfect way to move Scotland on from the current state of Brexit paralysis created by westminster and to move us towards independence.:SNP MP Joanna Cherry QC says Citizens Assembly is perfect way to advance independenceHer Twitter post was advertising an Electoral Reform Society event at Edinburgh University tomorrow about the Assembly in which she and Dr Escobar will participate.Dr Escobar, an expert in public policy at the Edinburgh, has advised SNP Brexit Secretary Michael Russell on the importance of ldquobuilding cross-party support for the Assembly.Also expected to be the lead researcher on the body, he told Scotland and Sunday that Ms Cherryrsquos comment was ldquocompletely against the ethos of such assembles.ldquoIm kind of fuming around that, adding an open-minded and unbiased approach was the "fundamental underpinning of the legitimacy of this body.He said: "I wouldnt be involved in advising, and hopefully soon to be confirmed in doing research around this,I believed that this was an already forgone conclusion."So earlier this week, when comments were made by a very prominent member of the SNP, it was perhaps the most unhelpful contribution that has been made so far to this process.ldquoI understand why this happens - it happens because theyre talking to their own supporters, they frame it in a way that is appealing to them. But it completely goes against the ethos."The person who made these comments has actually nothing to do with the Citizens Assembly. Shes not involved in organising it, shes not involved in any of the advisory boards. Shes just someone who has advocated for Citizens Assemblies because shes been inspired by the Irish example."Professor David Farrell of University College Dublin, research director on the first Irish assembly, also told the paper that perceived bias was ldquoa serious risk to the new project.He said: ldquoI think theres a serious riskthere isnt some buy-in from most of the parties that it could undermine it. Thats a serious risk."In both of the Irish processes, pretty much all of the parties were able to buy in - and in some cases quite reluctantly in the beginning. But I think that was so important.ldquoYou can see it with social media commentary already that there are people who are seeing this as a stitchup which is what you get early on. The best way to reduce that criticism is to say Look, we have some buy-in from all parties."We had much the same when we were talking about abortion because that would have been similarly an extremely controversial topic."So whats really important is that its seen to be independent, objective, fully transparent.":Citizens Assembly hit by recruitment delay amid Unionist calls for boycottDr Escobar told the Herald: ldquoWhat I really want to highlight is that there is a distinction, and itrsquos an important distinction, between public leaders like Joanna, who are advocates and supporters for this kind of methodology for involving the public, versus those who are actually impartial organisers who will have the responsibility to deliver this important process, and shersquos not part of that."I donrsquot think that thatrsquos a distinction that has been made properly.ldquoItrsquos all coming out as an attack on Joanna. To be honest, you know, these things very rarely get visibility, these kind of alternative forums of democractic engagement.ldquoTherefore it is important that leaders like Joanna and others come into that space and speak to their own supporters, which I think is what Joanna was saying when she said she was hopeful this is going to help the path to independence.ldquoBut the problem is that there is a public perception that this is just an SNP thing. But actually the Assembly is going to be independent from government.ldquoItrsquos important we are not mixing those who are advocates and public leaders who are calling for this, because they hope itrsquos going to help in their own cause, but that is not necessarily the agenda of the assembly, and certainly the organisers are a dferent sort of group.He went on: ldquoI do think that comments like that, because there is no public perception of the distinction between Joanna and the people actually involved in developing the Assembly, I think itrsquos true that these comments at this stage can make things much harder for people to really find some legitimate ground the Assembly to do its work properlywith public trust.ldquoBut, Joanna, you know, in that sense I donrsquot regret saying that. It does make it harder, until it will begin to distinguish between those who are speaking about the Assembly and calling for it, and those who are actually going to deliver an impartial process.Askedhe was concerned he had been misquoted, he said: "Speaking to the Scotsman I never mentioned Joannarsquos name, but obviously it was between the lines."I did say last week there were unhelpful comments that are making things ten times harder because we are not yet at the stage [of]a mature public conversation about what the Assembly could accomplishgiven the chance.ldquoIt just comes across as very personal, but then again Irsquom not that naive not to understand how things come out.ldquoUnless the Assembly has the trust of everyone across the ideological spectrum then itrsquos not going to work. Itrsquos important that people like Joanne speak up, but itrsquos just about understanding that shersquos not speaking up for ious assemblies, shersquos speaking up from her elected politician position and public leader position rather than anything to do with the actual delivery of the Assembly."I welcome contributions from politicians, but itrsquos just about how they choose to frame it.In a series of tweets this morning, Ms Cherry said she stood by her comment, and said it was part of the ldquojoy of democracy that others might disagree.However she also called for people to approach the Assembly with an ldquoopen mind.A short positive thread on #CitizensAssemblies #She told the Herald: "Of course Irsquom always interested in independence. Thatrsquos hardly a revelation. But the Citizens Assembly is about looking at policy issues which interest everyone regardless of their stance on Independence. The remit at present is wide."There are all sorts of future challenges the assembly could look at. Having pioneered this exciting initiative it would be surprisingI wanted to undermine it and I donrsquot."If there is a threat to the integrity of the CitizensAssembly it comes from those boycotting it andmisrepresenting its purpose. So I fully endorse David Martinrsquos call to those planning a boycott to think again."

title: kirsty-strickland-snp-must-stop-public-spats-ranks-focus-main-goal-independence
story: The Conservative Party has been torn apart by Brexit. It is not unusual to turn on the television and see Remain and Leave Tories squaring off against their colleagues with teeth bared looking for a weak spot to bite.The Labour infighting that has been on a rolling boil ever since Jeremy Corbyn became leader has been amplied by the row over anti-Semitism and Corbynrsquos inaction on Brexit.Where the two main parties have a long-established history of political cannibalism, the SNP ndash since the  referendum at least ndash has been united.:Kirsty Strickland: After Brexit, there is no way back to the politics of oldThe election of  SNP MPs in  was quickly followed by commentary on the eerie, too-good-to-be-true harmony within the group. They were called "robotsrsquorsquo and accused of almost cult-like deference and unquestioning loyalty to their party.But that was then, and this is now.This year wersquove seen tensions within the party spill over into the public arena.When Alex Salmond decided to take the Scottish Government to court over its handling of the sexual harassment complaints against him, lines were drawn between support for the former SNP leader on one side, and Sturgeon and her government on the other. It is characteristic of our politics that sides were picked long before any details of the case were aired in courtWhile the two former friends largely avoided the media frenzy that would have been provoked by a public war of words, their allies and supporters were far from quiet.The ision between the two big beasts of the SNP gave cover to those elected representatives who were already growing frustrated with the top brass.The timing of a second independence referendum and the strategy for securing one has been an issue that has caused unrest within the ranks. There are those who are anxious for another vote as soon as possible. They say the SNP leadership has been too meek in its approach and has failed to capitalise on the shambolic Brexit process.In the Halcyon Days before Twitter, party disagreements would be confined to smoke-filled meeting rooms or whispered briefings to hungry journalists. Now, as is the nature and curse of social media, we say exactly whatrsquos on our minds.These debates and disagreements between the politicians are being played out on Twitter and in the media. When we consider the speed with which the disunity spread it is dficult to see how some will manage to find their way back to a place of restraint.It is the proposed reform of the Gender Recognition Actthat has provoked some of the most open and often hostile warring among SNP politicians. The reforms would give transgender people the right to self-declare their gender, easing what supporters of reform say is currently an unnecessarily intrusive and distressing process.SNP figures such as Joan McAlpine and Joanna Cherry have been openly critical of their partyrsquos stance. Back in April,  SNP MPs and MSPs signed a joint letter in which they said that "changing the definition of male and female is a matter of profound signicance. It is not something we should rushrsquorsquo.The social media debate that has been rumbling on in the months since the letter was published has been the focus of much media attention, as SNP politicians battle publicly over what should happen next with the now-delayed proposed changes.When Mhairi Black posted a video recently in which she spoke about transphobia and the concerns some people have with the GRA, a few of her colleagues took to social media to comment.Councillor Chris McEleny tweeted to condemn the main SNP Twitter account for sharing the videoarguing that children might follow the account and be exposed to bad language.:Senior SNP figures in talks with Kremlin-linked bodies on UK tensionsJoan McAlpine dammed Mhairi Black with faint praise."Mhairi is a wonderful speaker. But she does not speak for @theSNP. She is one of k+ members who donrsquot think women have a penis. Letrsquos focus on getting independence. #priorities"Politicians will rightly speak up about issues which they care about and those issues will not always align, even within members of the same party. At this moment the SNPrsquos overriding priority should not be a futile quest to achieve universal agreement, but to gently remind its representatives of the political crisis we face. Social media spats in this moment of all moments look indulgent and counterproductive.A recent Panelbase poll for the Sunday Times showed that in the event of a Boris Johnson premiership, support for independence could rise to  per cent. While the usual disclaimers and caveats apply, this is signicant.Though many SNP politicians have been too busy fighting to remind the public of the political mandate to hold a second independence referendum ndash there is one.The party has won every election in Scotland since . They won an election on a manesto which stated that should Scotland be dragged out of the EU against its will, we should have the option of holding a second independence referendum. The Scottish Parliament has voted in favour of Indyref.What has been thus far missing from the equation has been the polling showing that the public mood towards independence had shted. With Boris Johnson in Number , we could be moving towards a situation where ndash for the first time since  ndash we start to see clear and consistent polling showing a majority for independence.It is ironic ndash and deeply frustrating for those who support independence ndash that the SNP have chosen now to abandon party discipline. As support for independence grows, the party who are defined by it seem to be drting apart.Of course, for every SNP politician who takes to Twitter in a pique of frustration, there are dozens more who keep quiet.Alison Thewliss is one of the Westminster grouprsquos most able and underrated MPs. She has been praised for her work on the two-child family cap and associated rape clause. Her impressive campaigning on drug consumption rooms in Glasgow has raised awareness of the issue.Thewliss is an effective and diligent MP. She is not one to chase the viral clip and she doesnrsquot take lumps out of her colleagues on Twitter. There is a lesson there for many SNP politicians. Next time they find themselves bashing out an angry tweet they should pause and ask themselves: what would Alison do

title: scottish-skiffies-invention-leads-record-world-championships-numbers
story: The skfie was created in  by Fe kit boat manufacturer, Alec Jordan after winning the backing of the Scottish Fisheries Museum in Anstruther and the internationally renowned designer Iain Oughtred, based on Skye, who was asked to come help with a plan for cheap ft boats that could be raced.Inspired by the traditional Fair Isle skf, their beauty was they came as flat pack kits to be built in community huts, initially cut from sheets of plywood, and initially sold for less than pound.While Mr Jordan initially was only expecting to sell a few dozen kits over "a few long years", he was amazed to find that the invention has taken off.Great day at the  SkfieWorlds Championships in Stranraer with a record  community crews from  clubs competing from across Scotland and even from Tasmania and Netherlands @StranraerSkf pic wuqyJITLwIn ten years it is estimated Scottish communities have built , there are  in England,  in the US,  in Australia and  in New Zealand. The next order is expected to be from China.:Scotlands greatest drives: Part twoAnd yesterday over a thousand rowers from around the world converged on the south west Scotland coastal town of Stranraer with their skfies to mark the tenth anniversary with the third world championships for the coastal rowing boat. The world championships have been held every three years since the inaugural event in Ullapool - with Stranraer winning the competitive bidding process to stage it in .Record entry numbers for the event in the sheltered water of Loch Ryanrsquos sea loch make this the biggest-ever SkfieWorlds.Organisers say the sport of racing what is more formally known as the St Ayles Class of coastal rowing boat is now one of the fastest-growing water sports in the world and it all starts with a community build of the craft itself.This community approach to boat building makes each and every skf unique many of them brightly-coloured and with quirky stories behind the boat names.An lsquooar salutersquo at SkfieWorlds by local members of the @PolScotPSYV #SkfieWorlds pic ZNTbpwNThe rowers joined thousands of spectators in watching the racing by teams of four from as far as New Zealand, Canada, Tasmania, the USA and mainland Europe.Some of this weeks races will be for those over sixty. The oldest rower in this weeks competition is eighty three.:Five aim to be first team to cross Minch in skf.. for MSWendi Cuffe, of Stranraer Coastal Rowing Club, said it was "truly spectacular" to see the skfs take to the water.These guys came from TASMANIA to row at Stranraer #skfieworlds pic dAwBiFvldquoWe have had an incredible start to SkfieWorlds and it has been amazing watching all these beautul skfs take to the water in Loch Ryan.ldquoEach and every one of these boats is a work of art, and each one has been built by ordinary folk, men, women and young people, coming together to share skills and create a community-owned boat that makes enjoying the water accessible and affordable for everyone.ldquoBecause, ultimately, St Ayles Skf racing is about building coastal communities as much as it is about building boats, and community building is something we know a fair bit about in Stranraer.More than half of those who race skfies are women, many in their forties.Mr Jordan says that this has surprised him, saying: "I was initially interested in creating a boat for coastal racing and was inspired by the Fe tradition of miners having boat races and was frankly surprised to find that my market was in fact often women whose children had fled the nest and wanted to get fit."The event also provides a  for Stranraer, formerly the main port to Northern Ireland, to reinvent itself as a leisure and marine tourism destination.:Water plan was hatched in rowboat on Indian OceanWith the ferries now stopping further up the coast, the clear waters of the Loch Ryan foreshore is available for tourism and recreation purposes, and there are ambitions to position the town as an international coastal water sports destination.SkfieWorlds is said by the organisers to be the largest event the town has hosted, and is expected to increase the population of Stranraer by a third.HRH The Princess Royal is introduced to #SkfieWorlds Project Manager Wendi Cuffe as she arrives at SkfieWorlds in #Stranraer @RoyalFamily @culturescotgov @VisitScotNews @EventScotNews pic UFyLAoTourism Secretary, Fiona Hyslop, who joined the Princess Royal in the event opening said: ldquoIt is little wonder that so many people want to come here to watch world championship rowing in a stunning setting, enjoying competitive sport whilst boosting local businesses and the wider economy.ldquoI am particularly pleased that the local community has embraced coastal and marine activities as we approach the Year of Scotlandrsquos Coasts and Waters in . I very much hope that many of those here this weekin the future to see more of what Scotland has to offer.

title: contest-champions-reinvention-scotlands-town-centres
story: And the search for Scotlands Most Beautul High Street which has entered its third year, comes with heartening signs town centres are making a comeback.The Carbuncles that named and shamed the countrys worst architecture for almost two decades, with its infamous Plook on the Plinth prize was scrapped in .That was the same year that Forres took the first ever Most Beautul High Street title.The third national competition has been launched by environmental charity Keep Scotland Beautul and Scotlandrsquos Towns Partnership with the winner to be chosen by a public vote.Travel video of Forres.It comes as the Scotlands Towns Partnership said that despite economic challenges, town centres are reinventing themselves.:Rab McNeil: Lets get back to having a high old time in our town centresThis has been helped with the carrot of a pound million fund developed by the Scottish Government to help boost struggling town centres.The largest beneficiary in the March allocation was Fe Council, which was receiving pound.m. Aberdeenshire was allocated pound.m, with poundm going to Glasgow and pound.m to Edinburgh.The smallest allocation - pound, - was awarded to Inverclyde.Phil Prentice, chief officer of the Scotlandrsquos Towns Partnership, said: ldquoOur high streets and town centres are the beating hearts of communities and local economies, and each has its unique identity and experience to offer for both residents and visitors. We want to celebrate the contribution of our high streets and recognise the efforts made to make these spaces clean, attractive, accessible, vibrant and inclusive for all to enjoy.ldquoAlthough some of our high streets have faced challenges in light of the growth of online retail, the spirit of reinvention is very much alive."Some towns have totally reinvented ndash Wigtown as the Book Town, West Kilbride as the Craft Town, Kirkcudbright as the Art Town, Oban for Seafood, Dunoon and Fort William as outdoor leisure specialists."Towns like Inverurie, Prestwick, Gourock and Kilmalcolm are all beginning to see a strong rise in the growth of independent and high quality local niche retail.Turrf became Scotlands jewel in the crown after coming victorious last year having been on a shortlist that included Cupar, Denny, Inverurie, Jedburgh and Linlithgow.Shortlisting judges are said to have previously taken a broad approach to the word lsquobeautulrsquo, focusing on factors such as horticultural achievement, public realm, environmental responsibility, access, inclusivity and community participation.The winning entry, submitted by Turrf Business Association, highlighted the townrsquos numerous heritage sites, horticultural beauty and community initiatives, including the iconic Turra Coo.Marj Chalmers, chairman of  winners Turrf Business Association, encouraged towns to get involved, stating: ldquoEntering and winning the title of Scotlands Most Beautul High Street last year was a great honour for us. Winning overall was fantastic and a great boost for Turrf. I would encourage anybody to take part as it greatly benefited us.: Michael Matheson: fundamental re-think of Scots town centres vital to pollution battleldquoWe had lots of press coverage and also television news coverage The footfall was increased greatly and it certainly put Turrf on the map with the businesses in Turrf benefiting from the extra trade.ldquoThe award that I and my colleague Rose Logan collected from the Parliament building in Edinburgh was proudly displayed around Turrf in members premises a week at a time and finally now has pride of place in our library."It was fantastic we won and was a big thank you to all the groups involved that keep Turrf spotless and beautul with hanging baskets and litter collection .In ,Urban Realm magazine, the organisers of the Carbuncles felt it was no longer appropriate to single out struggling communities at a time of continuing austerity and economic uncertainty.Cumbernauld in North Lanarkshire had the dubious distinction of winning the Plook on the Plinth title for having Scotlands "most dismal" town centre in  and .The Most Beautul High Street organisers feel their awards are valuable for accentuating the positives.Derek Robertson, chief executive at Keep Scotland Beautul, added:ldquoWe know that good quality environments are good for business and good for local people. Itrsquos inspiring to see so many communities and businesses across Scotland working together to improve the places they live and work in.ldquoFor over half a decade we have helped communities and local authorities improve the places they care for, through our Beautul Scotland competition."This opportunity to recognise the most beautul high street in the country will be a great celebration of those who are working together to ensure we can enjoy cleaner, greener and more sustainable places which help businesses and communities thrive.To enter the competition, a short description of up to  words with two high resolution High Street images is required explaining why it is deserving.The deadline for entries is pm on September . Entries will be shortlisted and the winner will then be chosen by an online public vote and announced during Scotlandrsquos Towns Week in November.

title: maritime-museum-recruits-help-restore-scotlands-historic-boats
story: Twenty two year old Edel McCarthy from Paisley is to join the Scottish Maritime Museum, home to some of Scotlands most historic boats and the countryrsquos largest collection of shipbuilding tools and machinery.She will join the museums Scottish Boat Building School in Irvine to learn traditional and modern boat building skills over the next three years and will play a key role in upcoming restoration projects.Those include the renovation of the  Vagrant, the oldest known yacht created by renowned Scots boat designer William Fe. It is thought to be the oldest surviving Clyde-built racing yacht.:National Museum of Scotland to reach decision onof Beothuk remains to NewfoundlandShe will also be involved in work to restore the William Fe-built  Golden Orfe Tender, a motor yacht that would have once been used to ferry passengers to and from a moored vessel. It was rescued by the museum from the Isle of Wight three years ago.It comes as it emerged  per cent of marine employees are reaching retirement age and about half of marine employers expect signicant proportions of their workforce to retire in the next five years.The trade association British Marine reported that % of Scottish companies have hard to fill vacancies as a direct result of skill shortages.The University of the Highlands and Islands has become one of the first institutions in Scotland to offer a new modern apprenticeship in boat building and repair.Ms McCarthys job will range from helping restore and maintain historic vessels in the Scottish Maritime Museumrsquos national heritage collection through to community skf building projects and commercial work.David Mann, director of the Scottish Maritime Museum, said: ldquoldquoWe have been a passionate advocate for this much-needed Modern Apprenticeship in Boat Building and Repair contributing to the major consultation during development. Wersquore delighted that it is now up and running and we can begin to help ensure, as a country, we retain our centuries old traditional boat building skills before they disappear.:Falls of Clyde is languishing in Honolulu harbourldquoAs stewards of Scotlandrsquos national maritime heritage collection, it is a boon for us to be able to help train the next generation of boat builders who can learn their trade restoring and maintaining some of Scotlandrsquos most historic and important vessels.Historic vessels at the museum include MV Spartan, the only surviving Scottish-built lsquopufferrsquo MV Kyles, the oldest Clydebuilt vessel still afloat in the UK Sy Carola, possibly the oldest seagoing steam yacht in the world and the three masted open sailing boat of , Lady Guilford, which is thought to be the oldest surviving Scottish-built boat.Other rare vessels include Katie, a fine example of a Zulu inshore line-fishing skf and Dodo, a small sailing dinghy built in a Glasgow townhouse bedroom in  by Walter Bergius who went on to found the firm that developed the Kelvin marine engine.

title: five-aim-first-team-cross-minch-skiff-ms
story: August  is the big day for the crew who are aiming to complete a -hour row, without the aid of a support boat, across the body of water between the Hebrides and mainland Scotland called the Minch to raise money for MS Society Scotland.They plan to pilot a ft skf an estimated , strokes from Stornoway to Ullapool and believe they would be the first team to do the crossing.:The Scottish flat pack boat invention thathas gone worldwidePhysically and mentally demanding, the challenge will take the group far beyond the distances travelled in their usual coastal rowing race season, requiring an estimated , strokes to pull them from the port in the Hebrides to the mainland.Kathryn Bennett, John Grant, Gary Lewis, Anthony OrsquoFlaherty and Lorraine Thomson will rotate as a crew of four rowers and a cox roughly every  minutes as they take to the open water.As part of their training they are taking on increasingly long rows alongside their regular fitness training and will participate in further fundraising activities including an indoor rowing marathon.Ms Thomson said: ldquoWe know that this part of the world has one of the highest rates of MS anywhere and we wanted to do something to raise funds and awareness of the condition.ldquoItrsquos our way of showing support, not only for those who have been diagnosed with MS but also for the people who care for them.This is a personal challenge for the crew who have friends and family members who have been diagnosed with MS.: hours in Lewis and HarrisThey picked the MS Society Scotland as their chosen charity for these personal reasons and due to the high prevalence of multiple sclerosisin the area.Northern Scotland has one of the highest rates of MS in the world and the MS Society is currently funding research projects across the UK to find more ndash and better ndash treatments for people living with the condition.The crew will navigate using GPS as part of an unassisted effort, leaving Stornoway at am and arriving around pm should all go to plan.They will be fighting the unsheltered conditions with blistered hands adding to the already daunting endurance challenge in their community-built boat, Cul Mor.Morna Simpkins, director of MS Society Scotland, said: ldquoThis is a truly incredible challenge to be taking on and we wish the crew the very best of luck in their preparations.ldquoOur supporters never fail to amaze me with their dedication and imagination in setting up and completing some amazing feats.ldquoMore than , of us in Scotland have MS and people raising funds and awareness is a crucial part of the fight to stop it in its tracks.

title: labour-set-agree-campaign-remain-referedum-tory-brexit-deal-unions-shift-policy
story: However, in the unionsrsquo agreed approach, Labour could still campaign for Brexitit won a general election and negotiated a good deal with Brussels.But a lack of clarity still exists as the union decision noted that Labourrsquos campaign position under such a scenario ldquoshould depend on the deal negotiated. This means theoretically that Labour could campaign against its own negotiated deal.Nonetheless, one senior Shadow Cabinet source described it as a ldquobig victory for Remain campaigners.The agreed line among trade unions, which included Unite, Unison and the GMB, is now likely to push the Shadow Cabinet to adopt the position when it meets on Tuesday.Tom Watson, the deputy leader, tweeted: ldquoRemain is who we are. Our values are Remain, our hearts are Remain. Today is a step in the right direction but our members and supporters are clear that any kind of Brexit gives us less than we have now and Labour should not support it.But Tom Brake for the Liberal Democrats claimed Labour was heading towards ldquoanother Brexit fudge.He said the unions had moved to support his partyrsquos policy to stop a Tory Brexit but a Labour Brexit would be no better. ldquoLabour must rule out their Brexit-supporting leader negotiating their own Brexit deal, Mr Brake added.

title: citizens-assembly-is-not-whether-scotland-independent
story: Former Scottish Labour MEP David Martin made the comments as he admitted it was a ldquomistake for Nicola Sturgeon to announce the scheme at the same time as she rebooted the debate on a future referendum.In a bid to ldquokeep the political temperature down, Mr Martin made a direct appeal to sceptics during an event in Edinburgh.:SNP MP Joanna Cherry QC has made Citizens Assembly ten times harder, says adviserHe said the Citizensrsquo Assembly ldquois not going to decide whether Scotland should have a second referendum, because thatrsquos a matter for the Scottish Parliament and the Scottish Government, and theyrsquove already legislated for that.He added: ldquoItrsquos not a matter of when the timing of that will be, because thatrsquos a matter for the Scottish Government and the British Government to negotiate.ldquoItrsquos not even a matter of what the question should be. Itrsquos not also a matter of whether Scotland should be an independent country or not.ldquoWhat it is, is trying to involve and inform citizens in as active and proactive a way as possible, so that when that choice comes wersquore all better informed and all better able to make that decision.Mr Martin, who is taking on the role of the Assemblys co-convener after losing his seat at the European elections, was speaking at an Electoral Reform Society event at Edinburgh University to discuss the proposals.It comes amid widespread Unionist scepticism over the plans ndash with both the Scottish Tories and Liberal Democrats refusing to have anything to do with the body, which will deliberate on issues relating to Scotlands future.Senior SNP MP Joanna Cherry QC also caused controversy aftercalling the process the"perfect way" to advance independence.Mr Martin said he hoped those urging a boycott would change their minds, but said he understood why the LibDems and Tories had adopted such a stance.He said this was ldquopartly because of the toxic nature of Scottish politics at the moment, but insisted a Citizensrsquo Assembly would help ldquolower the temperature and get a dialogue going.However, he criticised the way in which the scheme was unveiled by the First Minister in April, arguing the decision to announce it at the same time as legislation paving the way for a future referendum created suspicion.He said: ldquoSpeaking personally, not in the position of co-chair, I think with hindsight it was a mistake to have announced this as part of a three-course-of-action package.ldquoIt was announced at the same time as the indy debate, it was announced at the same time as the cross-party talks on the constitutional situation, and then the assembly was thrown in.ldquoAnd I think throwing the three things together has created some suspicion.ldquoI want to assure all political parties that they donrsquot need to be suspicious about this. This is a conversation they should want to be part of.But he added: ldquoIf they donrsquot take part, then nothing changes ndash because this is a Citizensrsquo Assembly. Therersquos no formal role for political parties anyway.Based on similar scheme in Ireland which led to referendums on same-sex marriage and abortion, Scotlandrsquos Citizensrsquo Assembly will see  members of the public chosen at random as a "microcosm" of society.They will consider long-term challenges facing Scotland over six weekends. However, the exact issues to be discussed are still unclear.:Tom Gordon: Citizens Assembly backlash is of the SNPrsquos makingAddressing the event in Edinburgh, Ms Cherry also insisted the Assembly ldquois not about whether or not Scotland should become an independent country.She added: ldquoMy personal view is that having a Citizensrsquo Assembly may assist on that path ndash others may think it may underline that the devolution we have is enough. Who knows.She also dismissed calls for a boycott, arguing ldquomost people are not [adherents of]one political party.She added: ldquoIf this boycott goes ahead ndash and I really have a lot of positive feelings that it wonrsquot ndash itrsquos not the same as boycotting an election or a referendum, because it will not be dficult to find  citizens who represent a cross-section of Scotland. I donrsquot think a boycott will destroy the assembly at all.

title: children-poor-areas-six-times-likely-pass-tobacco-shops
story: Researchers from Glasgow and Edinburgh universities used GPS trackers to follow a group of around  children aged  and  across the country to study their exposure to tobacco.They found that children from the most deprived areas were exposed to tobacco retailingaround  times a week ndash higher than the  times that those from the least deprived areas.Most exposure came from convenience stores and newsagents, with peaks just before and after school. There was also a higher than expected amount of exposure from supermarkets at weekends.: Quitting alcohol like giving up cigarettes in terms of health benefitsResearchers added that children from more deprived areas are more likely to start smoking themselves ndash and pre-adolescence is a critical period where the path to starting smoking begins.In a report published in the Tobacco Control journal, researchers said the dferences they found between the children were bigger than they had expected.A study earlier this year by a team from the universities of Edinburgh, Stirling and St Andrews indicated that tobacco outlets are twice as common in deprived areas.University of Glasgowrsquos Dr Fiona Caryl, lead author of the research, said: ldquoIdentying ways to reverse the normalising effects of ubiquitous tobacco retailing is key to policies aimed at preventing people from starting smoking.However, the use of GPS tracking highlighted previously unknown levels of exposure to tobacco retailing.: Computers to help diagnose disease and cut waiting timesDr Caryl added: ldquoOur findings provide a signicant contribution to the policy debate on tobacco availability.Professor Jamie Pearce from the University of Edinburgh said: ldquoThis exciting and novel work suggests any moves to reduce tobacco availability, whether to reduce the number of retail outlets or restrict the timing of sales, will have a greater benefit for more deprived groups who suffer the greatest amount of tobacco-related harm.It follows a blanket ban on the display of tobacco for sale across the UK in .Joseph Carter, of the British Lung Foundation Scotland, said that measures to further restrict the availability of tobacco should be considered.Mr Carter said: ldquoIf you live in a deprived area, you are three times more likely to die from lung cancer in Scotland. Clearly tobacco availability is playing a signicant role in driving the stark inequality in deaths from smoking-related lung disease.ldquoWe simply canrsquot accept a situation where children living in the most deprived areas should be exposed to these harmful products. We need to consider measures to further restrict the availability of tobacco, such as raising the age restriction at which you can purchase it to ."Lung disease is Scotlandrsquos biggest killer and tobacco plays a huge part in people developing chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and lung cancer in later le.ldquoPreventing people from taking up smoking in the first place is essential to give everyone in Scotland the chance to live well with healthy lungs.: MS breath test would be le changing, says patientDr Garth Reid at NHS Health Scotland said: ldquoAs a national health board working to reduce health inequalities and improve health... we welcome the findings, which will inform a report that we will publish later this year, considering the implications for health inequalities and tobacco control in Scotland in greater detail.

title: council-spends-6-000-fencing-stop-football
story: What was once a ldquobeautul grass area outside houses in Dalmuir, Clydebank, has become criss-crossed with low level black fences in the shape of an X.The cost, paid through the HRA Capital Investment Programme, is around pound,, according to the local authority. But the eyesore has been slated by residents, who accused West Dunbartonshire Council, which is run by an SNPindependent coalition, of wasting cash and spoiling childrenrsquos fun.The local authority admitted it would cost pound, ndash and was aimed at stopping children from playing outside.The fences are not completed at Auckland and Kingston Place but have provoked outrage, with the local SNP MP Martin Docherty-Hughes being contacted about the matter. Violet-Ann Woods said: ldquoDisgraceful move in my book and a total waste of money. Let the weans play. It does look like a prison ndash total overkill on fencing small areas like this. Put some swings on it for younger kids, [we are] meant to be encouraging kids to play outside.Tracey McCormick said: ldquoIt has to be the most ridiculous waste of money.ldquoThe grass areas in this scheme are the only safe place for young kids to play.ldquoThe people who complain should remember when they first moved in with their families. Irsquom sure they had many happy memories of playing there. It is now a total eyesore.A petition has been handed in to the council citing objections. An eight-year-old boy told of his dismay at no longer being able to play football on the grass.Charlie Quinn said: ldquoI just donrsquot really like it. A lot of the time, me and my friends would always play football here but now we canrsquot play as far up because of the fence. I donrsquot like it at all.His grandmother, Ann McElhinney, , said her other grandchildren who come to visit will no longer enjoying playing there. The grandmother-of-seven said: ldquoI just think itrsquos shocking.ldquoI have grandchildren who come and visit me. Sothey are not allowed to play here it means they have to go to areas where there are a lot of cars. I donrsquot allow them to do that.ldquoWe have had kids kicking the ball over our garden fences but the children are so polite and they will ask to come in and take the ball. Itrsquos very young kids, between nine and . The kids will all hate this.ldquoAlso, the way the fence is shaped, how do they plan on getting in the middle to cut the grass  It means the grass will be a mess. Diane White, , described it as ldquodangerous.The grandmother-of-six feared the fencing would pose a risk to childrenthey tried to climb it.She said: ldquoI would get itthey put a fence on the outside of the area to stop balls from rolling into peoplersquos gardens. But the bit in the middle is just a no-no.ldquoSomeone is going to get hurt. One of the kids will try and climb that and they will fall and hit the other fence.ldquoI think itrsquos actually more dangerous."A spokesman for the council said: ldquoThe low level fences were introduced in consultation with residents following a number of complaints about damage to property caused by ball games on the grassed area.ldquoThe design was chosen to discourage use of the location as a play area and encourage the use of existing full-size pitches nearby.

Were hopeful of running up a big win for Jeremy north of the border," he added.Camleys Cartoon: Hunt in the lead in ScotlandMeanwhile, Borders backbencher John Lamont, Mr Huntrsquos Scotland campaign manager, stressed how Mr Johnson had said he was willing to extend the post-Brexit Implementation Period to  but made clear keeping the UK in the CFP would be ldquocompletely unacceptable for Scotlandrsquos fishermen."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Boris Johnson vs Jeremy Hunt: Tory leadership candidates quizzed bywriters","description": "Boris Johnson vs Jeremy Hunt: Tory leadership candidates quizzed bywriters","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs zhXdITx-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests zhXdITx.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": ldquoAnything less than leaving the CFP by December  would be a betrayal of Scotland, declared Mr Lamont.But the Johnson camp hit back, insisting Brexit by October  was necessary to regain control of UK fishing waters. ldquoThis is the only way we avoid a betrayal of the people," it said.

title: herald-diary-mixed-response-sharp-reply
story: JAMES Thomson from Jordanhill was sweating it out in the heat of London at the weekend and tells us: "While waiting for an underground train I noticed on the wall that there was a poster for a leading tonic brand. Its caption was If   of your drink is the mixer, mix with the best." Another traveller was reading this and said in a loud Scottish voice, If   of your drink is the mixer, Irsquod ****** pour your drink again."Didnt buy itOUR stories about the police reminded reader John Crawford: "Years ago I was stopped by a patrol car on Brockburn Road in Pollok. After the usual question, Do you know the speed limit here sir  which I was well over, I was asked: Whats the rush  I said I was late for a meeting with a buyer at Babcocks who was a stickler for punctuality. As American Samantha Ruddy commented: "Man, for a country that doesnrsquot care about women or soccer, we are bloody amazing at womenrsquos soccer."Turned to jellyNIGEL Farage condemning Britains Ambassador to America for telling the truth about Donald Trump reminds us of when Nigel was being touted as a possible replacement as ambassador. However the most inspired suggestion was Hillary Clinton.: : ldquoIrsquom delighted my old home has been saved for the futureStar struckWE asked for your stories about the Moon landing which was  years ago this month.
